Puerto Colombia, un municipio a la orilla del Mar Caribe, donD.  vive con su esposa y su hijo D. 6 años D. edad, con el que sueña verlo convertido en un  profesional exitoso; Luis Alberto  tiene un negocio en el barrio El Porvenir D. la ciudad D. Barranquilla, llamado “Tienda y Salsamentaría Surtiya Norte”, donD. venD. productos e insumos para la preparación D. comidas rápidas, como salsas, carnes frías, queso y desechables; él tiene como su principal desafío ampliar su capital, para obtener descuentos por pago efectivo y por mayor volumen D. compra. Su meta más adelante es ubicar otro punto comercial en el corredor universitario D. la ciudad D. Barranquilla y comprar un vehículo para atender los pedidos a domicilio  oportunamente.  Luis Alberto  en su negocio maneja  una competencia fuerte,  a la que responD. exitosamente mediante  una oferta D. productos y servicios D. calidad y ofreciendo precios muy competitivos, con  eso se sostiene en el mercado y maneja un margen D. utilidad  promedia no menor a  un 20% y con una rotación D. inventarios D. 10 días. Este es el primer financiamiento 	que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y con el comprará   carnes frías, salsas, productos desechables, queso, verduras y panes pues se acercan días feriados que aumentan el potencial D. ventas y Luis Alberto debe estar preparado para ello.
texts.en: Luis Alberto D. C. P.  is 33 years old and a resident of Puerto Colombia, a town on the shores of the Carribbean. He lives there with his wife and 6 year old son, whom he dreams of seeing become a successful professional. Luis Alberto has a business in the neighborhood of El Porvenir in the city of Barranquilla, called “Tienda y Salsamentaría Surtiya Norte”, where he sells products and ingredients for the preparation of fast food, such as sauces, cold cuts, cheese and disposable products. His main challenge is growing his capital to get discounts for paying upfront and having a higher volume of purchase. His goal in the future is to have another sales locale in the university corridor in the city of Barranquilla, and to buy a vehicle to fill delivery orders quickly. Luis Alberto deals with strong competition in his business and is able to respond successfully by offering quality products and services and competitive products. In this way, he maintains himself in the market and has an average profit margin of  20% with a 10 day inventory turnover. This is his first loan with the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo and with it, he will buy cold cuts, sauces, disposable products, cheese and bread. Some holidays are coming up and the sales potential increases. Luis Alberto has to be ready for it.

loans.use: to buy cols cuts, sauces, disposable products, cheese, vegetables and bread.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic U. is from the village of Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 31 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Marivic owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) shop, buying and selling canned goods, junk foods, shampoo, soap, biscuits, detergents and beverages in the local community. She also provides motorela or habal-habal services with her husband as the driver. Marivic has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Marivic joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marivic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase additional inventory and to increase working capital. Marivic is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, instant noodles and beverages. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Marivic from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, instant noodles and beverages.

location.town: Tumpagon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Milly

texts.en:
Milly is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala central region of Uganda.  She is married and has two children.  All of her children are currently in school.  Milly has a business of tailoring, which she has had for eight years.         

To help expand her business, Milly has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase more materials for making clothes for resale.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Milly hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children.  In the future, Milly hopes to buy a plot of land.  Milly is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by helping her improve in her business.

loans.use: to purchase more materials for making clothes for resale.

loans.name: Maria Iraida

texts.es:
Maria es una mujer de 30  años de edad,  está casada y tiene 2 hijos en edad escolar. Esta familia vive en una zona urbano marginal del distrito de Mórrope- Lambayeque. La comunidad donde María  vive, es  una comunidad pequeña de gente emprendedora y trabajadora.    

La actividad que desarrolla María es la crianza y comercialización de animales, labor que realiza hace 4 años, teniendo experiencia otorgada por su madre con la cual inicio este negocio. Actualmente María cuenta con ganado porcino.

Ella solicita a Edpyme Alternativa un préstamo de 1500 nuevos soles para  invertir en la compra de alimento balanceado para sus cerdos y en la culminación de acabados en el interior de su domicilio, que le son de gran necesidad. María tiene muchos deseos de mejorar su calidad de vida y este préstamo le sería muy útil. Ella ya ha trabajado con nuestra institución y  goza de un buen historial crediticio.
texts.en:
Maria is a 30-year-old woman.  She’s married and has two school aged children.  This family lives in a marginal urban zone in Mórrope-Lambayeque District.  The community where Maria lives is a small community of enterprising, hard working people.

Maria raises small farm animals to sell, a job she’s been doing for four years, having gained experience from her mother who she started the business with.  Currently, Maria raises pigs.

She asks Edpyme Alternativa for a 1500 new sol loan to buy nutritionally balanced pig feed and to finish doing some interior home improvements that are much needed.  Maria has a strong wish to improve her quality of life and this loan will be very useful for her.  She has worked with our institution previously and has a good credit history.

loans.use: to buy nutritionally balanced animal feed and to do some home improvements.

loans.name: Efrenia

texts.en:
Efrenia is 37 years old and lives in Villa Sudiacal, Liloy. She is married with one child. 

To earn a living, Efrenia has a business selling snacks. She earns about PHP 3,000 each month doing this type of work. Efrenia has requested a loan to purchase raw ingredients for her snack vending business.

Efrenia has been a member of PMPC for two years.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients for her snack-vending business.

location.town: Liloy-Villa Sudiacal, Liloy, ZAmboanga Del Norte

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a farmer in the Nyamira area of the Rift Valley province, Kenya. She has been in farming for over 30 years, producing and selling bananas, maize, beans, and coffee in the the local market. She is married with six children, of whom the last born is the only one still in school. She has two farm hands in her farm.

Jane has requested a loan of 46,800 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says the dairy cow will improve her income and her family's standard of living. Jane is optimistic that the business will continue to grow and she will be able to buy a motor vehicle to help her deliver her produce as well as enable her to venture into the transportation business for more income.

Jane sees finances as the limitation in the farming business, especially for the purchase of farming supplies like fertilizers.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Lyra

texts.en:
Lyra is a married woman with 5 children. The oldest child is 16 years old and the youngest is 9. Lyra's husband is a farmer.

Lyra has had a sari-sari (variety) store business for 12 years. She sells items like sugar, vinegar, coffee and canned goods to the people in her community. She also helps her husband sell his harvest at the market. She works hard to help provide their household needs and send her children to school.

She is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP to buy more items to sell such as noodles and canned goods, and to buy school supplies for her children. In the future, Lyra hopes to improve their house.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell such as noodles and canned goods, and to buy school supplies for her children.

loans.name: 4 Nam Ngạn Group

texts.en:
Ms Luận works in agriculture raising poultry and cattle. She is requesting a loan to purchase calves to raise and resell.

Luận is 61 years old and single with four children. She is the group leader of the 4 Nam Ngạn solidarity group, which consists of four members. 
She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, an urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with no dependents.

In 2008, Luận joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Luận has successfully repaid five loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She has been involved in this business for more than 10 years.

The main hardship that Luận faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Luận hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her children to find a good job, and to maintain a successful business.

loans.use: to purchase calves to raise and resell.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa is a thirty-four-year old single mother of three children.  She rents a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been tailoring and selling clothes for six years.  

Hawa started with 500,000 shillings and now has 10,000,000 shillings as her working capital. Her hardships are high prices for goods and bad debtors.  Her dream is having another shop and building a house.  Hawa needs this loan to buy clothes and shoes to resell.

loans.use: buy clothes and shoes to resell

loans.name: Abbas

texts.en:
Abbas is a 20-year-old single Lebanese man living with his parents and three siblings. He has been working as a car mechanic for the past four years.  Today he is the proud owner of a car repair shop. His work is specialized in changing car wheels and repairing smashed ones. 

With his requested loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l., he will be able to improve his business by purchasing additional tools needed. He states that these purchases will allow him to act faster while repairing cars. In the future, he is hoping to enlarge his shop and add new service which consists in selling car spare parts.

loans.use: to improve his business by purchasing additional tools needed

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is 33 years old and has a child who goes to elementary school. Aside from farming, she also runs a sari-sari (variety) store to make additional income. She sells grocery items to the people in her village. Through farming, she earns a yield twice a year amounting to P25,000. Her spouse plows the farm land and Gladys helps transplant rice seedlings. As they cannot do all the activities, they need additional laborers. So she is asking for a loan of P10,000 to buy seeds and pay laborers to help transplant rice seedlings. 

In the future, she would like to achieve an abundant harvest every cropping season to save for the college education of her child.

loans.use: to buy seeds and pay farm laborers who help in transplanting rice seedlings in the field.

loans.name: Norte Poty Group

texts.es:
El grupo Norte Poty es un comité de 19 mujeres que son muy bien organizadas, unidas, trabajadoras y solidarias unas con otras. Estas señoras son de la ciudad de Villarrica, y todas son vecinas y amigas. Se reúnen quincenalmente para brindarse apoyo y ayuda las unas a las otras. Estas señoras están muy animadas para seguir participando en este programa de microcrédito, pues han mejorando mucho sus ingresos económicos. Ademas de las actividades solidarias que tienen, en este grupo manifestaron que tienen un sueño de abrir una microempresa y que podrían trabajar juntas. Van a seguir esforzándose en esto, y tienen todas mucho ánimo de seguir creciendo en el futuro y de esa forma mejorar el nivel de vida de sus familias.
Una de las miembros es la señora Juana, ella se dedica a la lavandería, comenta que su trabajo es duro, pues diariamente recibe muchas prendas para lavar. Gracias a este trabajo ella ha podido sacar adelante a su familia y poder paliar los gastos que diariamente surgen en la casa.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de suavizantes, detergentes en polvo y demás insumos necesarios para la lavandería. Agradece a la Fundación por la oportunidad que esta le brinda.
texts.en:
The group “Norte Poty” is a committee of 19 women who are well-organized, united, hardworking, and supportive of one another. These women are from the city of Villarrica and are all friends and neighbors. They meet every 15 days in order to provide support and assistance to one another. These women are very excited about continuing their participation in this microcredit program so that they can greatly improve their income. In addition their group activities, the members say that they dream of opening a microenterprise and being able to work together. They continue to strive for this goal and have great excitement about continuing to grow in the future so that they can improve the standard of living for their families.

One of the members is Sra. Juana, who has a laundry business. She says that her work is hard because she receives many clothes to wash every day. Thanks to her work, Juana has been able to help her family move forward and to provide for the daily expenses incurred by her household. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy fabric softeners, powdered detergents, and additional supplies that are necessary for doing laundry. She is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya for the opportunity that has been given to her.

loans.use: to buy fabric softeners, powdered detergents, and additional laundry supplies.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is 32 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is single with 1 child. Rose has operated a retail shop for 6 years, selling canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages. Rose is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Rose hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Asumani

texts.en:
Asumani is 45 years old and lives in the town of Arua in the Luwero region of Uganda. He is married and has 9 children with 7 of them currently in school. For the past 20 years, Asumani has been working hard to manage his butcher shop, which sells fresh cuts of meat. 

To help expand his business, Asumani has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more cattle, and will help Asumani to generate greater profits and pay for his children's school fees. Asumani hopes that in the future he will be able to continuing to expand his business by taking out larger loans from BRAC. 

Asumani is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Asumani who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more cattle for butchering

loans.name: Wilmer

texts.en: Wilmer is 31 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is single. Wilmer is providing motorcycle or habal-habal services. He has had this business for two years. He requested a loan for 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy tools and pay for the gasoline for maintenance. Wilmer is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Wilmer hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy tools and pay for the gasoline for maintenance.

loans.name: Jeanet Del Socorro

texts.es: Jeaneth Del Socorro tiene su negocio que es la venta de ropa nueva. Desde hace más de 21 años que tiene de poseer este medio de vida, ella es una persona muy trabajadora y le da mucho orgullo el tener su propio negocio. Ella tiene su negocio establecido en el mercado en donde la mayoría de sus clientes saben que ella siempre está ofreciendo buen servicio y precios accesibles. El crédito es para la compra de ropa interior, camisas para mujeres, vestidos, faldas, trajes para niños entre otros.
texts.en: Jeaneth Del Socorro sells new clothing. She has done this for over 21 years. She is a very hard-working person and she is very proud to have her own business. Her business is established in a market, and the majority of her customers know that she is always there, offering a good service and accessible prices. This loan is for the purchase of underwear, women's shirts, dresses, skirts, and children's outfits, among other items.

loans.use: to buy underwear, women's shirts, dresses, skirts, and children's outfits.

loans.name: Amba Shg Group

texts.en:
Stephen is the facilitator of the Amba SHG group. Stephen and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Stephen and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Stephen takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Stephen had a very good maize yield harvesting 16 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Stephen was only able to harvest six bags of maize on one acre of land.

With income from his maize sales, Stephen will educate his children and save for future use.

In 2012, the members of Amba SHG group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

The photograph shows Stephen pictured together with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace  is a fishmonger and also sells food stuff at Besease near Elmina. She is married to a farmer and has three children. Grace has been in the fish and food stuff business for the past three years and she assists her husband with the upkeep of their children. 

Grace is requesting a loan to purchase more fish and food stuff for sale. She will use the profit from her loan to expand her business.

loans.use: purchase more fish and food stuff for sale

loans.name: Eden

texts.en:
Eden is 40 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children. 

Eden has a shop that sells bananas and coconuts for copra. She has had this business for ten years. She requested a loan of PHP 9,000 to buy bananas and coconuts to sell.

Eden has been a member of HSPFI since 2007. In the future, Eden hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy bananas and coconuts to sell.

loans.name: Denny Adenir

texts.es: Denny Adenir de 35 años de edad, habita en casa familiar con su  compañera de vida  y sus tres hijos. Denny es un hombre trabajador el cual no se cansa de luchar día con día por el bienestar de su familia. Su principal inspiración es su familia la cual lo motiva a trabajar duramente para darles una calidad de vida diferente a la que él ha tenido. Él se dedica totalmente a su negocio que ha establecido desde hace barios años. Su negocio es una peluquería en la cual se pueden hacer diversidad de cortes de cabello en especial para los caballeros. Ha tomado la decisión de solicitar este crédito a INTEGRAL con el objetivo de mejorar sus servicios de tal forma que esto permita atraer a nuevos clientes. Por lo tanto el crédito lo solicita para invertir en: tijeras, brochas, peines, gel, etc. Confía plenamente en Dios y en su trabajo que de esta manera logrará su objetivo.
texts.en: Denny Adenir, age 35, lives with his partner and three children in their family home. Denny is a hard-working man who never gets tired of working hard for his family's well being, day in and day out. His family is his main inspiration. They motivate him to work hard in order to give them a quality of life better than the one he has had. He is completely dedicated to his business, which he established several years ago. He runs a barber shop, where he can do various hair cuts, especially for men. He has decided to request this loan from INTEGRAL with the goal of improving his services in order to attract more clientele. He will invest this loan in: scissors, shaving brushes, combs, gel, etc. He trusts in God completely, and in his work--this is how he will achieve his goals.

loans.use: to buy: scissors, shaving brushes, combs, gel, etc.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is 30 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is single with one child. 

Evangeline has a food shop (sari-sari store) that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Evangeline has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Evangeline hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

loans.name: Maram

texts.en:
Maram is a 20 year divorcee woman from Al Khaledieh Al Mafraq Jordan. She is requesting a loan of 600 JOD to pay for clothes to sell,she wants to expand her project and she hopes to increase her income. In the future she would like to buy a home.
Since Maram is under 30 year old, her loan is considered a youth loan.

loans.use: to pay for clothes to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 48 years old, married and together with his spouse, has been blessed with four children. He sells livestock in Nakuru town and he has been in this business for the past 15 years.

He plans to use this loan to buy more sheep and goats to sell. He will use the anticipated profits to expand his business. 

This is his first loan from VisionFund Kenya and his future hopes are to buy land.

loans.use: To buy sheep and goats to  sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Irene would like to buy more mosquitoe nets

loans.name: Fofoa

texts.en: Fofoa, who is 55, hails from the village of Lalomauga, where she lives with her husband and five kids. Her husband helps her with their taro plantation, located not far from her house. She takes 3-4 bags of taro to be sold at the market twice a week. She earns more than $300.00 a day from her sales. She uses money earned from the business to buy other things for her business to help better and improve the growth of her plantation so that this source of income does not die or run out. It also helps with the purchases of food for her family.

loans.use: To purchase 1 box of cramoxone.

loans.name: Viviana

texts.en:
Viviana has 20 years of experience in her photography business. She learned this business from her parents, since she has liked it since she was young. She saved money from her job to buy her own cameras. She achieved this and was able to become independent. Her husband has always helped her, and in his free time he also does photography. She works every day of the week from 8:00 AM until 6:00 PM. If she has evening events, especially on the weekends, she works then, too.

Viviana wants the loan in order to invest in buying rolls of film. There have been times when she hasn’t been able to work because she didn’t have film. She would also like to be able to repair a camera that has a problem.

Viviana is married. She is 45 years old. She has three children who are studying and in their free time, they help her in her business. Her husband works as a guard at a hospital in the city. In the future, she hopes to be able to finish her house in order to give a better life to her family.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Viviana tiene una experiencia de 20 años con su servicio de toma de fotografías. Actividad que la adquirió de sus padres ya que ella desde joven le gusto. Con su trabajo fue ahorrando para comprar sus propias cámaras. Lo logro y se independizo. Siempre con la ayuda de su esposo el cual en sus ratos libres también se dedica a la toma de fotos. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 8 a.m. hasta las 6 p.m. Si tiene eventos por las noches sobre todo los fines de semana también trabaja.

Viviana desea el crédito para poder invertir en la compra de rollos de fotos. Ya que en algunos casos ella no puede realizar su trabajo por que no posee en existencia. Además desea poder repara una cámara que tiene una falla.

Viviana es casada. Tiene 45 años. Su familia se compone de 3 hijos los que estudian y en sus ratos libres le acompañan a ella en su negocio. Su esposo trabaja de guardia en un hospital de la ciudad. A futuro espera poder terminar su casita para darle una mejor vida a su familia.

loans.use: To buy rolls of film and to fix a camera

loans.name: Francisca Juliana

texts.en:
Francisca Juliana Tale, 46, has been growing her little corner store for 20 years. She started it when her husband broke his leg and injured his spine, and has had it going ever since. She started out with an investment of just 20 Guatemalan Quetzals (maybe US$5.00 at the time) by buying just a few snack items and some tortillas. Through reinvestment of her profits over the years, she's grown it into a business that almost supports the whole family and has a pretty good stock. Some of her best customers are the children who pass by on the way to and from school. She has most things anyone could want for daily use, including snack food and soft drinks, flour, sugar, salt, and a fair selection of pharmacy items that are unusual in a little store like this.

Francisca's husband did eventually return to work, but his back deteriorated and he now does not work outside the store. The store now (almost) supports the family, but the monthly payments for school for the youngest three children are still a bit of a crisis every month. She's hopes with great hope for their schooling and that they'll have a better life than she has had.

Francisca is a member of the women's group "Mujeres Prudentes" and will use this credit, like the previous ones, to finance the purchase of merchandise for the store.

loans.use: Purchase Inventory for store

loans.name: Iraida Aurelia

texts.es:
Iraida has a five year old daughter. In order to provide for her better she decided to invest her savings and open a small shop in her home. Though it began very modestly, the shop has prospered thanks to Iraida's good cheer and patience. It is now one of the most popular shops in the neighborhood. With more customers, Iraida would like to expand the products she offers so she can better serve the community. She is asking to borrow $100 and promises to repay the loan in 6 months. Please help make Iraida's dream a reality.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Iraida, es madre de una pequeña niña de 5 años y por el deseo innato de brindarle lo mejor, decide implementar con un monto pequeño que tenía como ahorro familiar, una bodeguita en su casa. A principio la bodeguita no parecía ser un negocio rentable pero, Iraida, con la amabilidad y paciencia que la caracteriza la convirtió en un a de las más visitadas.El número de clientes que tiene se ha ido incrementando y con ellos la demanda de más cantidad y variedad de productos por ello es que ha decidido acrecentar la cantidad de productos y servicios que ofrece en este pequeño espacio a su comunidad.A raíz de este hecho es que Iraida, solicita un préstamo de 100 dólares con el compromiso de retornarlos es un lapso de 6 meses para iniciar la implementación y compra de productos para su pequeña tienda. Hagamos que el sueño de Iraida, se haga realidad con tu ayuda podremos lograrlo.

loans.use: To stock a grocery store with more varied merchandise.

loans.name: María

texts.en:
Maria V., 45, is married to Carlos V., 50, and lives in Paraguarí, Paraguay where she owns a small grocery. Together she and Carlos have two children who already have jobs and homes of their own. Though her husband has a job as a construction worker, Maria decided she also wanted to contribute to the household income by opening her own store.

Maria began her grocery in her house several years ago. As business grew, she decided to move her store closer to the municipal market. Proceeding with this plan and with the willing hands of her sons, who had finished school, she was able to open her store with success.

With the credit she will obtain, Maria plans to buy greater quantities of merchandise, including breads, dairy products and drinks. All of these items are in high demand. She wishes to satisfy her growing customer base as well as increase her monthly income.

loans.use: To purchase greater quantities of merchandise, including breads, dairy products and drinks.

loans.name: Mirvary

texts.en: Mirvary H. (her daughter is pictured) is a widow. She was born in 1972. Mirvary with her daughter live in Salyan region, in the village of Yenikand. She started a farming business 15 years ago. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy a plot of land for improving her business.

loans.use: Buy a plot of land

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Miss Cynthia O. is 38 years old, single and lives in Benin City. There, she is a beautician who also sells bags and shoes.

Miss O. is requesting a loan of $450 to buy more bags and shoes for sale. She had learned the business for 18 months before starting her own business in 2001. She is a committed client of LAPO.

loans.use: To buy bags, shoes, and Ssaloon materials for sale

loans.name: Alminda Albina's Group

texts.en:
Vilma and Alminda have been members of the community bank “Luz Divina” for four months and seven years respectively.  In the community bank they have learned to be punctual, responsible, independent, and how to handle money and makes decisions.
Vilma is 27 years old, and by profession a nurse.  She sells grains in the markets of Ayacucho.  Now, with the help of her father, she is growing potatoes and corn.  In addition Vilma works as a nurse.
Meanwhile Alminda is 46 years old.  She is married and has four children.  Alminda has a business preserving fish.  She sells her products throughout the region of Ayacucho.  She is planning to open a new business selling cebiche, a traditional dish made from marinating fish.  Eventually she would like to have several cebiche restaurants.  
Vilma and Alminda need loans of 300 and 1500 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy fertilizers, pay laborers, tables, and chairs.
One of the key aspects of the community bank is the interest earning savings account each associate has.  Vilma and Alminda plan to use their savings to expand their business, pay for their children’s education, and get a nursing specialization.  Their dreams are that their children will be professionals, they can help their family and younger siblings, and to be secure economically

loans.use: Vilma and Alminda need loans of 300 and 1500 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy fertilizers, pay laborers, tables, and chairs.

loans.name: Bimala

texts.en:
Bimala C. lives in Khokhana Dobato with her husband and two sons, and with her father-in-law and mother-in-law. Her father-in-law and mother-in-law are elderly and cannot work, while her sons are in grades 2 and 6.

Her husband, Sudip C., is a taxi driver. However, his income is not enough for them to run their family smoothly. So Bimala decided to work their land, growing seasonal vegetables. She sells her vegetables in the local market in the morning and evening, every day. Now Bimala is requesting Rs 30000.00 (USD $475) to buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Kong S. is 40 years of age and makes 4 USD per day, buying pepper from provincial farms and reselling it at a low markup. Her husband (pictured here as she was unavailable to be photographed) works for the ministry of forestry in Kampong Cham province, earning only 2 US$ per day.

Two of their three children are already married and live outside the family home. She wants to use her loan to purchase pepper in bulk in order to increase her profits. She hopes to some day purchase a plot of land so that she can store the pepper for resale when market prices are too high.

loans.use: To purchase pepper in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Elizabety

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Elizabety M.. She is single and has 4 children aged between 7 and 21. She has 2 dependents. In 2004 Elizabety established her liquor store business. Elizabety requires a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of beer and soft drinks. She thanks you for your support.

It is said that Coca Cola® is one of the most recognized symbols or "words" in the world. And it’s true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of "bar" selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness (Pepsi has made it to most African capitals but not to the rural areas, but I’m sure they’re working on it!). The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing: a very cheap marketing tool. All of which explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture, whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola Ltd in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania!

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of beer and soft drinks in bulk

loans.name: Helyn Martinez

texts.es:
Helyn Martínez is a hard-working and dedicated woman who raises cattle and has her own calves, which feed her community in Villanueva de Chinandega.

According to Helyn, she began her business with a minimal number of animals (calves) but little bit little as time has passed she has been able to acquire greater quantities of calves. She raises the calves and then sells them, which is the cycle of her business. Today she is requesting support in the form of a loan from Ceprodel. With the loan, she will be able to purchase more calves which will allow her to continue her business and thus maintain her household.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

Helyn Martínez es una dama que con mucho esfuerzo y dedicación se dedica a la labor de la ganadería contando con terneros propios los cuales alimenta en su comunidad en Villanueva de Chinandega.

Según comenta su negocio lo inició teniendo las mínimas cantidades de animales (terneros) pero a medida que ha venido transcurriendo el tiempo ha logrado adquirir mayores cantidades de terneros los cuales los cría, y comercializa siendo este su ciclo de negocio. Hoy en día busca apoyo en Ceprodel para ser beneficiada por medio de los créditos otorgados por Ceprodel. Por medio de ellos logrará la adquisición de los terneros el cual le urgen para continuar con su negocio y por ende con el mantenimiento de su hogar.

loans.use: Purchase calves

loans.name: Morn

texts.en:
Morn S., 51, is a widow who lives in Kampong Cham with her four children. Two of her daughters work in the Phnom Penh garment factories, earning US$ 130 each month, while one child is a student and the other is still too young to attend school. Morn S. works as a farmer and typically makes US$ 1 each day out in the fields. She would like to cut down on unnecessary expenses and increase her family’s income.

Morn S. has asked for a loan of US$ 300 to purchase a motorbike for her daughters to use to commute to work. She has seen how the price of public transportation has risen rapidly with the increase in gas prices and she believes that the family can save some money through this purchase. She would like to see her standard of living improved through the increased income and looks forward to the results of this investment.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Godfroid

texts.en:
Greetings from Rwamagana in Rwanda! Godfroid is a 45-year-old entrepreneur, married with five children, one adopted after being orphaned in the 1994 Genocide. Before the  Rwandan Genocide, Godfroid made his income selling dairy products from his cows. During the Genocide, the cows were slaughtered and his house destroyed.

In 1997, Godfroid started a business selling agricultural produce including bananas, sorghum, and beans, and was able to open a small shop in his home area. Earning about $280 every month, he employs two people to help him run the business and is now applying for a loan of $925 to increase his stock for the growing food market in the area.

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Salima

texts.en:
Salima M. is 42 years old. She is a very wise and hard-working woman. She is married, with three children. The children attend the public school of the town. This entrepreneur dedicates herself to the sale of shoes for men and women. Salima admits that lending services from IMON have helped her business grow over the past 8 years.

Little by little, she has expanded her inventory and thanks to the good service she offers, her business is growing rapidly. She says that with income from her business she is able to provide education and food for her children.

Now Salima needs a loan of 2000 Somoni which she will use to buy merchandise to meet the demand of her clients and to continue growing her business. She is committed to paying back this loan in 3 months. This is the time to help someone who needs it. Please do not hesitate to help improve the quality of life of this family.

loans.use: Purchasing autumn shoes for men and women for re-sale

loans.name: Amira

texts.en: Amira A. comes from Babići, a small village near Gračanica. She is a mother of  two sons who are students. Her husband works out of Bosnia and she is spending her time taking care of her children. Her occupation is tailoring. She works at her home on one old machine. That machine does not have many functions and Amira is forced just to repair clothes. She wants to take a loan from WWI in the amount of 1500 KM to buy a new machine. She hopes to expand her business and earn more.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Gafaratou

texts.fr: Née vers 1979  à Sakété dans le département du Plateau au sud BENIN, dame B. Gafaratou est mariée et mère d'un enfant âgé de cinq ans.  Elle est revendeuse des perles, des produits de soins corporels et d'autres petits produits de beautés. Pour accroître sa capacité à satisfaire ses clients et pour faire face à la demande de sa clientèle en période de fête, elle sollicite son premier crédit afin de ne pas connaître une rupture de stock en période de fête.
texts.en:
Born around 1979 in Sakété in the Plateau Province in the south of Benin, Mrs. Gafaratou B. is married and the mother of a 5-year-old child. She sells beads, cosmetics and various other little beauty products. To boost her ability to saisfy her clientele and meet demand in the holiday period, she is requesting her first loan so that she will not find herself without certain products during the holidays.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of two dozen strings of beads and 2 cases of pommades

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married and has no children. She sells womens' clothing at the central market in Melitopol. Since she is the owner, she can keep prices low to attract many customers. Irina has been in this business for two years. Her relatives were very supportive and helped her business grow. Irina was able to increase her monthly gross income to 10,000 UAH.

Irina is requesting a loan of 4,000 UAH to increase the variety of goods she sells. She believes that having more goods can bring her additional income. This would help her pay for her increased family expenses during in winter.

loans.use: To purchase more goods

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.en:
Muhabbat M. sees herself as a calm, hardworking and responsible person. She began her business due to the need for an income additional to her husband’s to cover the household expenses. They have a child who grows each day, as do their economical needs. She began some time ago selling different products and even had a homemade-food shop, which she had to close because of the increase in the shop’s rent. So, one of her friends convinced her to sell clothes and offered to take her to places where she could buy clothes at good prices. She followed her friend’s advice and began to sell clothes 12 years ago. Her sales went very well. She now has a fair number of clients. Muhabbat asks for 1500 Somoni ($450), which she will pay back in 10 months, to purchase seasonal garments. She wants to take advantage of the dates and have a more diverse variety of garments for her clients, which will allow her to increase her sales. 

More information about Tajikistan and IMON International: 

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road, the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and the birthplace of the great Persian poet Rudaki and the most famous Islamic philosopher Ibn Sina (Avicenna). The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History: 
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.

loans.use: Purchasing children's clothing to sell

loans.name: Nurush

texts.en: Nurush G. is a very optimistic man in spite of the circumstances he has endured. He is 54 years old and married with five children. Nurush raises cattle, and he uses the income to support his family. He has a great appreciation for animals and wishes to increase his cattle business and therefore increase his earnings. He hopes that you can help him by funding his loan. Nurush is a trusted client who has already successfully repaid a loan from AqroInvest. You could become an important part of his family's life. Nurush deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

loans.use: To purchase two calves

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret W. is currently in the business of selling bread and eggs. Margret is 39 years old and married. Her husband is a nurse at the hospital. She has four children and they all go to school. She is requesting a loan to expand the business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business selling bread and eggs.

loans.name: Ghulam Fatima M. Hanif Group

texts.en:
Ghulam Fatima baji is a 58-year-old married woman who has lived in Borewala, Pakistan for the past 35 years. Her husband, M. H., has run a tea stall in the community for the past 3 years. Fatima baji is the mother of two children: one son and one daughter. Her son drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Her daughter is 12 years old and reads in 8th standard. 

Fatima baji is a seamstress. She sews clothes to share the financial burden of her husband. She successfully repaid her two previous loans from Asasah, a microfinance institute in Pakistan. Now she is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for her son. 

She is a the leader of a group of women in her locality. Mukhtaran baji wants a loan to buy an animal to sell. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics to sell. Kosar baji wants a loan to buy a lath machine. Another woman, also named Mukhtaran baji, wants a loan to buy leather to sell. 

 This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: 'Baji,' which means 'older sister,' is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Benkadi (Entente) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est composé de cinq femmes mariées vivant majoritairement dans des familles monogamiques avec en moyenne  35 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent ensemble dans le quartier Rails Ko de Markala (4ème région administrative de la république du Mali) où elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et  d’amitié.
Elles ont connu Soro Yiriwaso suite à une assemblée générale tenue à la Mairie de la  commune rurale de Markala à l’intention des Artisans et petits Entrepreneurs de la dite localité. Elles excellent dans le secteur de l’alimentaire (restauration, fabrication de boisson non alcoolisées, ventes de produits alimentaires etc.).  
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles décidèrent d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 4ème prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe), après avoir correctement remboursés les trois premiers.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter 2 sacs d’oignons frais,1 bassine de tomates fraîches,  2 bassines de gombo séché dont une partie est transformée en poudre, 2 cartons de poissons séchés, 2 sacs de fonio,1sac de graines d’arachide transformées en (Djouga : couscous à base de fonio et d’arachide), 2 cartons de pommes de terre vendues sous forme de fritures et de ragoûts ; 2 sacs de sucre, 1sac de gingembre,1sac d’oseille de Guinée, 25 kg de lait en poudre et 1 carton d’essence (arômes) pour la préparation des boissons (gingembre, dableni : jus de feuilles d’oseille de Guinée et yaourt). 
Elles se ravitaillent en pomme de terre, fonio et arachide à Sikasso et quant aux produits pour les boissons locales et les condiments  à la foire de Diamarabougou. Elles vendent au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes, de femmes et d’enfants à domicile en ambulant, dans les gargotes et au marché. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  mensuel moyen de 43 750FCFA qui servira pour le remboursement du prêt et à l’achat des fournitures scolaires des enfants. Leur objectif est d’avoir une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The group Benkadi is composed of five married women living for the most part in monogamous families. The women average 35 years of age and 5 children each. They live together in the Rails Ko district of Markala (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali), where they know one another through ties of community and friendship. They were knowledgeable of Soro Yiriwaso (a micro-finance institution) following a general assembly held at the town hall of the rural community of Markala that was intended for artisans and small-scale entrepreneurs of the aforementioned town. The women excel in the food sector (restaurants, selling grocery items, etc.)

Concerned with satisfying their customers, they decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program and are now on their fourth solidarity loan (group loan) after having correctly repaid the first three. This loan will be used to buy: two sacks of fresh onions, one basin of fresh tomatoes, two basins of dried okra (a portion in powdered form), two sacks of fonio (a kind of millet), one sack of peanuts for making into djouga (couscous made of fonio and peanuts), two boxes of potatoes to be sold fried or stewed, two sacks of sugar, one sack of ginger, one sack of dried hibiscus flowers, 25 kg of powdered milk, and one box of flavorings for making beverages (ginger and dableni: a drink of hibiscus flower and yoghurt).

Supplies of potatoes, fonio, and peanuts are gotten in Sikasso. As for the goods for making local beverages and the condiments, these are gotten at the Diamarabougou fair. Sales are made to customers composed of men, women, and children, cash or credit accepted, at the house, door-to-door, in eateries, and at the marketplace.

The group members hope to realize an average monthly profit of 43,750 francs CFA for making loan payments and for buying school supplies for the children. Their objective is to have a house for living in.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments and essential ingredient for making a local dish (djouga) and local beverages

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Saroeun L., 53, and her husband, Heng Min, 55, live on Island of Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Married in 1979 they have five children: two sons and three daughters. Two of her daughters who are silk weavers, were married but live inside the family home. Another daughter is learning tailoring skill, one son is a teacher and the other attends school. Besides her children, she also has two sons in-law and four grandchildren living with her.

Saroeun has been selling desserts at the local market for four years and she weave silk as well. Her husband raises cows. She lacks the money to purchase more silk materials to continue her weaving business. So she is requesting a loan of $150 to purchase silk material for her weaving business.

loans.use: Purchase silk material for her weaving business.

loans.name: Amor Y Paz Group

texts.es:
El grupo Amor y Paz , son mujeres que se llevan bien, sociables, responsables con deseos de de superarse, son vecinas cercanas, Doña LUXY tiene 36 años, tiene tres años de tener su pulperia, esta ubicada en un sector estrategico donde tiene bastante demanda, sus clientes son sus vecinos y 
y personas que transitan el lugar, ella se levanta muy temprano a abrir su negocio y lo cierra a las diez de la noche , ella vende pañales, papel higienico, arroz, manteca,  café, azucar, maseca, margarina, salsa, la cliente invierte a la semana $ 300.00 Y gana $ 83.00. ella necesita el credito para comprar mas productos como ser refrescos, maseca, manteca, arroz, jugos espaguettis, frijoles, y asi tener mas surtida su pulperia ya que el sueño de la cliente es verla mas grande, y a la vez obtener mejores ganancias.
 DOÑA IRIS se dedica a la venta de golosinas, charamuscas y gelatinas desde hace seis años ella las va a vender a la escuela de la colonia ya que sus clientes son los alumnos y vecinos ella es una persona agradable, sociable, querida por los niños , ella les lleva a vender tacos, chilaquiles, tamalitos de frijoles paletas, la cliente compra a la semana $ 37.00 y  gana $ 73.00 de esta forma le ayuda a su esposo al sustento ya que tienen tres hijos, ella necesita nuestro apoyo para comprar zapatos nuevos, comesticos, ropa clasificada, ya que anteiormente ella se dedicaba a la venta de ropa su sueño es poner su negocio bien fuerte y hacer profesionales sus hijos.
 DOÑA GLADYS ella se dedica a la venta de tortillas desde hace cinco años, sus clientes son sus vecinos asi mismo tiene clientes fijos  y a la vez surte cafeterias y  casetas en Plaza Loarque, ya que desde niña le gustaba hacer tortillas, ella compra a la semana $ 45,00 gana  $ 75.00, la cliente le ayuda a su esposo ya que tiene  3 hijos en la escuela y de esta forma han podido salir adelante ,el sueño de ella es verlos profesionales, el credito lo necesita para comprar maiz leña,cal.
  WILFIDA tiene 26 años ella se dedica a la venta de tortillas desde hace tres años,ya que desde pequeña le ayudaba a su mama a vender tortillas,  sus clientes son sus vecinos, y tiene clientes fijos a los que les entrega a diario la cliente compra a la semana $ 50,00 gana $ 70,00 , el sueño de ella es vender mas ya que necesita credito para comprar materia prima (maiz, maseca, leña y cal)
texts.en:
The Amor & Paz Group are comprised of women who get along well, are sociable who are tasked with the desire to overcome obstacles and are close-by neighbors.

Ms. Luxy is 36-years old and has owned a shop for the last 3-years. This business is located in a strategic sector where there is great demand. She clients are her neighbors and passers-by. She’s open for busy very early in the morning and closes her doors at 10 PM. She sells napkins, toilet paper, rice, butter, coffee, sugar, Maseca (brand of corn), margarine, salsa. It costs $300.00 per week to maintain, yet she only earns $83. Lucy needs credit to purchase more items like refreshments, Maseca, butter, rice, spaghetti sauce, beans as she’d like to have a very diverse shop. She dreams to see her pool of clients grow and hopes to gain good profits.

Ms. Iris has been committed to the sale of candy, snacks and jellies for the last 6-years. She goes to the schools in her colony as well as to students and neighbors to sell her products. She is a very well liked, very sociable person who cares for the children. She starts by selling tacos, chilli’s and bean tamales which cost $37.00, but generate $73 of income. With this form of help she will be able to support her husband and three children. She needs our help to buy new shoes, cosmetics and a uniform to be presentable as she was engaged in the sale of clothing. Her dream is to have a thriving business and to have her children become professionals one day.

Ms. Gladys has been engaged in the sales of tortillas for the last 5-years. Her clients are her neighbors and she also has clients at her kiosk and sometimes finds luck by the cafés in the Loarque Plaza. The children love to have tortillas. She spends $45 a week on materials but earns $75 for her efforts. The customers help her support her husband and three children who are in school and will have the opportunity to get ahead. Her dream is to see them become professionals and the loan is needed to purchase corn, wood and lime.

Ms. Wilfida is 26-years old and has been engaged to the sale of tortillas for the last 3-years. She will need a little assistance to help her mother sell tortillas. Her clients are her neighbors, as well, and she also has clients at the kiosks that she encounters daily. The materials cost $50.00, but she earns $70.00 per week. Her dream is to sell much and the much needed credit will allow her to buy premium material (corn, maseca, wood and lime).

Translated from Spanish by Jenson Abraham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase various general store items.

loans.name: Enriqueta

texts.es: Doña Enriqueta es soltera, tiene 40 años deedad y es trabajadora del Hospital Asuncion como secretaria desde hace 20 años, tiene una hija de 18 años, el proximo año iniciara una carrera universitaria, esta solicitando su 5to credito el que utilizara para levantar una pared al fondo de su casa para evitar que la corriente del invierno le deteriore su casa, en un futuro esta pared sera utilizada para la construccion de un dormitorio.  Doña Enriqueta no tiene apoyo de nadie, ademas de su trabajo de lunes a viernes, los fines de semana vende cosmeticos con lo que se ayuda para los gastos del hogar y algun otro compromiso, sus creditos anteriores los ha cancelado en tiempo y forma, demostrando hasta la fecha un excelente record crediticio.
texts.en:
Enriqueta is single, 40 years old and has worked as a secretary at Aunción Hospital for 20 years. She has an 18 year old daughter who will start university next year. She is requesting her fifth loan that will be used to build a wall in the back of her home to keep the winter waters from damaging her house. In the future this wall will be used for the construction of a bedroom. Enriqueta doesn't have help from anyone and besides, her work is from Monday to Friday and on the weekends she sells cosmetics and that helps with household expenses and another commitment. Her previous loans were paid on time which proves up until now she has an excellent credit record.

Translated from Spanish by Hugh Yarbrough, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a wall

loans.name: Ouyètiè 2 Group

texts.fr:
Ouyètiè 2 est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de Nitabogoro de la ville de Koutiala région de Sikasso(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies avec leurs enfants, maris, beaux parents, belles sœurs  etc. Elles ont en moyenne 29 ans et au moins 6 enfants.
Elles excellent principalement  dans la culture de l’arachide et du haricot.
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe Ouyètiè 2 ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant  2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semences d’arachide, de haricot, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, au grand marché de Koutiala ville.  
Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Koutiala et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant à une clientèle généralement  constituée de revendeurs  venant des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe Ouyètiè 2 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 65 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Ouyètiè 2 is a group of married women who live in the Nitabogoro neighborhood in the city of Koutiala (Sikasso Region, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in large extended traditional families with their children, husbands, in-laws, etc. They average 29 years of age, and have at least 6 children. They mostly specialize in cultivating peanuts and beans. Eager to make their cultures profitable, the members of the group Ouyètiè 2 decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, two years ago. After having repaid the first loan without problem, they are now seeking their second farming loan. The new loan will be used to buy, at the grand market in Koutiala, a sufficient quantity of peanuts seeds, beans, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields. After the rainy season, crops are stored for a while to gain market value, before being sold at the grand market in Koutiala and in the surrounding villages, retail (often wholesale) and for cash, to a clientele of resellers usually coming from the larger cities. After selling their production, the members of the group Ouyètiè 2 count on turning a profit of XOF 65'000 (ca US$ 140) each, to be used to repay the loan and to pay for the daily expenses of the family.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanuts seeds, beans, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields

loans.name: Osuman

texts.en: Osuman S. is married and has 6 dependants. He has received no formal education. Osuman sells cattle and parts of animals which are of interest to tourists at Abotoase, a town near Hohoe, Ghana. He has been in this business for a long time. Osuman uses his income to pay for housekeeping expenses. Osuman will use the loan to purchase more cattle. With the resulting profits, Osuman plans to reinvest into his business.

loans.use: Osuman will use the loan to purchase more cattle.

loans.name: İslam

texts.en: İslam M. is a married father of two sons. His family lives in Agsu city where İslam runs a small grocery store downtown. İslam's store is well known in the neighborhood as he serves his customers well and works late hours, which is very convenient for many customers who work late and go shopping after they are done with work. İslam has been in business for 9 years. Currently he is seeking a loan of 2000 USD to purchase more inventory, so he can increase the variety of goods he offers. İslam had some struggles when his business was growing and becoming self-sustainable, but he handled all those challenges pretty well and is looking toward the future with much enthusiasm and optimism.

loans.use: purchase more inventory to increase the variety of goods

loans.name: Isa

texts.en:
Isa was born in 1956. He is married and has four children. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Azerbaijan Fuzuli region. He is now settled in Fuzuli region, in the Bala Bahmanli village.

Eighteen years ago, he started his business. He sells medicines for animals. The drugstore is for animals. Now he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy medicines for animals in order to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy medicines for animals

loans.name: Melania Isabel

texts.es:
Melania Isabel C. F. es una señora de 67 años de edad, quien vive,  en una pequeña comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada San José de Upala, localizada en la  Provincia de Alajuela. Ahí se desarrollan actividades como el comercio, ganadería de doble propósito (carne y le che) y agricultura.
 
Doña Melania es viuda y tiene 3 hijos pero ya todos son mayores de edad por lo tanto no viven con ella pero si la ayudan  con diferentes gastos.  Doña Melania se dedica a la ganadería de leche, específicamente produce leche queso y otros  derivados;  los cuales vende tanto en su comunidad como en lugares vecinos, que según su criterio, hay un excelente mercado ya sea por medio de venta a intermediarios o al público directamente. 

Doña Melania  considera que gracias al progreso de este proyecto, sus condiciones de vida han mejorado mucho, también comenta que desde que inicio con el negocio su autoestima ha mejorado y ahora se siente muy capaz, dice que ha crecido mucho a nivel personal y profesional.

Doña Melania es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Mujeres la Esperanza; la cual está integrada solo por mujeres, ya que se especializa en apoyar a mujeres no profesionales y  jefas de hogar, es una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su sexto  préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Melania Isabel C. F. is 67. She lives in San José de Upala, a small rural community in Costa Rica, which is located in the Alajuela province. The community activities are business, dual purpose livestock (meat and milk), and agriculture. Mealnia is a widow with three children. The children are grown and do not live with her, but they do help with different expenses. Melania works in milk production. Specifically, she produces cheese made from milk and other milk derivatives. She sells to her community and to neighboring places. She feels there is an excellent market selling to intermediaries or directly to the public. Melania feels that thanks to the progress of this project, her living conditions have improved a lot. She also says that since the start of her business her self esteem has improved. She now feels very capable. She has grown a lot on a personal and professional level. Melania is a member of the Women’s Communal Credit Union La Esperanza. Its members are only women because they specialize in helping women who are not professionals and heads of households. It is one of the 100 organizations partnered with EDESA in Costa Rica. This is her sixth loan. She hopes to continue growing on and personal and economic level with the loan. She also plans to actively participate in the credit organization in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy three cows

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina is a member of the Dodoma Road borrower group in Kihesa,Morogoro,she is 28 years old woman.

christina started her own Tailoring business 5 years ago,she works 8 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 75,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Christina`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more materials for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Christina hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more material for her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and fabrics.

loans.name: Ana Isabel

texts.es: La Señora Ana Isabel P. tiene 56 años, hace más de 15 años que se decida a este negocio como es la elaboración de cajetas de cocos, esta actividad económica viene de familia, su Mama quien le enseño como se elaboran estos dulces que son muy ricos y apetecidos por sus clientes. Desde la edad de 15 años Ana sabía pelar cocos la fruta que se utiliza para la elaboración de los dulces, ya que todos los días tenía que levantarse temprano para ayudarle a su Mama algunas veces salía a las calles a vender. Actualmente ella se hace cargo, de este negocio ya que es uno de los trabajos que más le gusta además tiene que salir a las calles y ofrecer sus dulces. Ella solicita el financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de azúcar, leña, cocos, leche entre otras cosas. El sueño de Ana es proporciónale mejoras a su vivienda.

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: Tabitha

texts.en:
Tabitha is 27 years old, is married to Patrick, and is blessed with two sons and one daughter.

Tabitha was introduced to KADET through an existing member. She is planning to expand and increase the stock for her greengrocery business. This will also enable her to increase her number of clients because her greengrocery targets customers who buy in both retail and wholesale.

Tabitha intends to purchase a dairy cow with the extra profit she earns. Her future hopes and dreams are to expand her business and to be able to purchase farm produce directly from farmers so that she cannot be exploited and will be able to make more profit.

Tabitha describes herself as an ambitious lady, a visionary and a hardworking lady.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website:  www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To increase the stock in her greengrocery business

loans.name: Mellianita

texts.en: Mellianita M. is from the village of Sugarland, Valencia City. She is 45 years old, is widowed, and has four adult children. Mellianita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Mellianita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hel

texts.en:
Hel S., 33, was married years ago and her marriage has resulted in seven children who are still young and attend school.

She has been operating a small handicraft business since 2000. S. has a skill of making local basket accessories by hand with bamboo, while her husband has a skill of decorating wood for building.

Hel S. wants to earn more income by operating another line of work.

Because Hel S. doesn't have adequate money, she would like to ask for a loan from Kiva through HKL to be used to order rice in bulk to resell to raise her income.

loans.use: To order rice in bulk to resell.

loans.name: Nena

texts.en: She's a 69 year-old widow who continues to earn her own living because she wants to stay independent and also continue to help her children establish their own lives. Nena G. has been a widow since 2006 and lives in the village of Barangay Palaka, Pulupandan, Negros Occidental. Her husband's death was a great loss to the family and since all of her seven children are grown up with their own families, Nena wanted to remain independent and be able to earn a living so that she could provide for her old age. Years ago Nena put up her general store to help her husband to raise income of the family to support its needs, especially as they had seven children. She said when she started her business, she found it quite hard to look after the needs of her children and at the same time handle the business, but she coped with all the hardships with much determination. Because of Nena’s hard work, her business grew, and she joined NWTF Project Dungganon (NWTF-PD) in 1998 so that she could access more capital for her business. With new capital infusion, she expanded her product offerings to include guinamos (shrimp paste) which is a popular flavoring and dish in the Philippines. She also traveled to other towns to sell her shrimp paste. Her guinamos was so popular that she now has regular customers, some from other towns, who prefer to buy their shrimp paste exclusively from her. Now, Nena earns a monthly income of PHP 18,000 and she saves most of this for her future security and for emergencies. She sometimes uses some of it to help out her children. Nena’s previous loan of Php 15,000 was used in her business as additional capital and it was repaid within her loan term in full and on-time, maintaining her good standing as an NWTF-PD member. Now she is borrowing Php 20,000 for her 15th loan to be utilized for her general store and her guinamos business. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stocking up her shop

loans.name: Baatarhuu

texts.en:
Baatarhuu is 56 years old and lives his wife and three children in Khovd Province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a "ger," which is a yurt or traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. His oldest son, who is 27 years old, works to help with the family's earnings. His second son, who is 22 years old, attends the university. His youngest goes to a local secondary school. 

Baatarhuu and his wife sell meat in their town. He started his business in 1998. After growing his business and stabilizing his income, he expanded his business by starting a taxi service with the car that he bought. 

Baatarhuu is a very hard-working businessman who is focused on achieving his goals. He says, "I will be happy if I can give my children a good and happy life." He is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug (~$1050 USD) loan to purchase meat to sell in his business.

loans.use: To purchase meat to sell

loans.name: Dié

texts.fr: Dié TALL es une femme de 44 ans, elle est célibataire sans enfant mais elle a la garde et charge de ses 2 nièces. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 5 ans et fait de l'embouche ovine. Ses revenus lui permettent d'entretenir les enfants qui sont à sa charge et de subvenir à ses propres besoins.
texts.en:
Dié TALL is a 44-year-old woman, unmarried, without children, but she provides support for her two nieces who are under her care. She has been a member of the local ‘Banc Villageois’ loan group for five years, and fattens sheep for a living. Her earnings provide for the children under her care and meet her own needs.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolster her capacity for investment

loans.name: Santos Alfredo

texts.es:
Es Sr. Santos Alfredo L. C. es conductor en n organismo internacional en el departamento de Estelí. El solicita un crédito el que será utilizado en la matricula de la universidad de su hija menor, ya que su hija esta cursando el quinto año de universidad y que así ella logre ser una profesional.

El empezó a trabajar como conductor en un organismo internacional que se dedica a la conservación y buen uso de el agua, antes que el se dedicara a esta labor era conductor en una institución del estado. Cabe señalar que el Sr. Santos L. a trabajado como conductor para dicho organismo desde hace tres años, el trabaja todos los días de lunes a sábado desde las 7 de la mañana y no tiene hora de salida ya que es un trabajó muy pesado y a veces tienen que trabajar fuera de horario para cumplir metas.

El espera que con dicho crédito su hija lleve a cabo y logre matricularse en el quinto año de su universidad y así logre ser una profesional y obtener sus metas en un fututo así como ser una persona totalmente independiente.

Santos Alfredo L.  es originario de este municipio, casado y con dos hijas una de ellas es independiente y su hija menor es estudiante aun y vive con el.

Este es el tercer crédito que ha tenido en un periodo de 6 años, Santos L. dice que con los crédito que a obtenido en Ceprodel a llevado a cabo algunos proyectos que por cuenta propia no los hubiese realizado ya que los ingresos mensuales de el son  bajo y no suficiente para realizar dichos proyectos por cuenta propia por lo que se muestra agradecido con Ceprodel.
texts.en:
Sr. Santos Alfredo L. C. works in the Department of Estelí as a driver for an international organization. He is requesting a loan to pay for the college registration fees of his youngest daughter. She is starting her fifth year of university and hopes to become a professional.

He began working as a driver for an international organization dedicated to water conservation and management. Previously, Santos worked as a driver for a state institution. It should be noted that Santos began working for his current employer three years ago. He works every day, Monday through Saturday, starting at 7am. There is no established time to go home because his workload is very heavy and sometimes requires him to work after hours to meet his deadlines.

Santos hopes that this loan will help his daughter complete her registration so that she can start her fifth year of college. She has future aspirations of becoming a professional and a totally independent person.

Santos Alfredo L. is a native of this city, married, and has two daughters. One is independent and the the other one is a student and still lives at home. This is the third loan he has received within the past six years. Santos says that with the loans he has received from CEPRODEL, he has been able to undertake a few projects on his own. Since these projects would not be possible because of his low monthly salary, Santos says he is grateful to CEPRODEL.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for his daughter's college registration expenses

loans.name: Martine

texts.fr: G. Martine est née en 1972 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Il y a trois ans que Martine vit au quartier Dandji à Cotonou.  Martine est mariée à ZANNOU Joël, un maçon, et mère de trois enfants.  Tous les enfants de Martine sont scolarisés.  Martine vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille.  Martine a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire.  Depuis deux ans Martine vend du côme (aliment préparé à base de maïs), accompagné de poissons frits au Carrefour Abattoir à Cotonou.  C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, qu’elle s’approvisionne. Martine a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Marine sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer ses activités et maximiser son profit.
texts.en:
G. Martine was born in 1972 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has been living in the Dandji district in Cotonou for three years.  She is married to ZANNOU Joël, a mason, and is the mother of three children. All her children are in school.  She lives together with her husband and children.  The couple jointly support the family.  Martine has attended secondary school.  For two years, she has been selling côme (a food made from corn) served with fried fish, at Carrefour Abattoir in Cotonou.  She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She has already benefited from an ALIDé loan, which she has repaid.  Martine is requesting a second loan from ALIDé for bolstering her business and maximizing her profit. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying corn, fish, condiments

loans.name: Bina

texts.en:
